name: draw2d
description: Primary package containing general interfaces and implementation classes.

classes.name: Canvas
classes.description: A scrolling Canvas that contains Figures. Call add(draw2d.Figure) to add shapes to the Viewport.

functions.name: init
functions.description: Create a new canvas with the given HTML DOM references.

parameters.name: canvasId
parameters.description: the id of the DOM element to use a parent container

functions.name: destroy
functions.description: Call this method if you didn't need the canvas anymore. The method unregister all even handlers and frees all resources. The canvas is unusable after this call

functions.name: clear
functions.description:
Reset the canvas and delete all model elements.
You can now reload another model to the canvas with a {@link draw2d.io.Reader}

functions.name: hideDecoration
functions.description: Callback for any kind of image export tools to trigger the canvas to hide all unwanted decorations. The method is called e.g. from the draw2d.io.png.Writer

functions.name: showDecoration
functions.description: callback method for any image export writer to reactivate the decoration of the canvas. e.g. grids, rulers,...

functions.name: calculateConnectionIntersection
functions.description: Calculate all connection intersection of the canvas. Required for "bridging" or "crossing decoration"

functions.name: installEditPolicy
functions.description: Install a new selection and edit policy into the canvas

functions.name: uninstallEditPolicy
functions.description: UnInstall the selection and edit policy from the canvas.

functions.name: setZoom
functions.description:
Set the new zoom factor for the canvas. The value must be between [0.01..10]

// you can register an eventhandler if the zoom factor did change
canvas.on("zoom", function(emitterFigure, zoomData){
    alert("canvas zoomed to:"+zoomData.factor);
});

parameters.name: zoomFactor
parameters.description: new zoom factor.

parameters.name: animated
parameters.description: set it to true for smooth zoom in/out

functions.name: getZoom
functions.description: Return the current zoom factor of the canvas.

functions.name: getDimension
functions.description: Return the dimension of the drawing area

functions.name: setDimension
functions.description: Tells the canvas to resize. If you do not specific any parameters the canvas will attempt to determine the height and width by the enclosing bounding box of all elements and set the dimension accordingly. If you would like to set the dimension explicitly pass in an draw2d.geo.Rectangle or an object with height and width properties.

parameters.name: dim
parameters.description: the dimension to set or null for autodetect

functions.name: fromDocumentToCanvasCoordinate
functions.description: Transforms a document coordinate to canvas coordinate.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: the x coordinate relative to the window

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: the y coordinate relative to the window

returns.description: The coordinate in relation to the canvas [0,0] position

functions.name: fromCanvasToDocumentCoordinate
functions.description: Transforms a canvas coordinate to document coordinate.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: the x coordinate in the canvas

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: the y coordinate in the canvas

returns.description: the coordinate in relation to the document [0,0] position

functions.name: getHtmlContainer
functions.description: The DOM host of the canvas

functions.name: _getEvent
functions.description: Return a common event object independed if we run on an iPad or desktop.

returns.description: the left scroll offset of the canvas

functions.name: getWidth
functions.description: Return the width of the canvas

functions.name: getHeight
functions.description: Return the height of the canvas.

functions.name: add
functions.description:
Add a figure at the given x/y coordinate. This method fires an event.

Example:

canvas.on("figure:add", function(emitter, event){
   alert("figure added:");
});

// or more general if you want catch all figure related events
//
canvas.on("figure", function(emitter, event){
   // use event.figure.getCanvas()===null to determine if the
   // figure part of the canvas

   alert("figure added or removed:");
});

parameters.name: figure
parameters.description: The figure to add.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The new x coordinate of the figure or the x/y coordinate if it is an draw2d.geo.Point

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y position.

functions.name: remove
functions.description:
Remove a figure or connection from the Canvas. This method fires an event which can be catched.

Example:

canvas.on("figure:remove", function(emitter, event){
   alert("figure removed:");
});

// or more general if you want catch all figure related events
//
canvas.on("figure", function(emitter, event){
   // use event.figure.getCanvas()===null to determine if the
   // figure part of the canvas

   alert("figure added or removed:");
});

parameters.name: figure
parameters.description: The figure to remove

functions.name: registerPort
functions.description: Register a port to the canvas. This is required for other ports to find a valid drop target.

parameters.name: port
parameters.description: The new port which has been added to the Canvas.

functions.name: unregisterPort
functions.description: Remove a port from the internal cnavas registration. Now other ports can't find the port anymore as drop target. The port itself is still visible.

parameters.name: port
parameters.description: The port to unregister as potential drop target

functions.name: getAllPorts
functions.description: Return all ports in the canvas

functions.name: getCommandStack
functions.description: Returns the command stack for the Canvas. Required for undo/redo support.

functions.name: getPrimarySelection

Set the current selected figure or figures in the canvas.

You can hand over a draw2d.util.ArrayList since version 4.8.0 for multiple selection.

parameters.name: object
parameters.description: The figure or list of figures to select.

functions.name: addSelection
functions.description: Add the current figure to the selection. If a single selection policy is installed in the canvas the selection before is reseted and the figure is the one and only selection.

parameters.name: object
parameters.description: The figure(s) to add to the selection

functions.name: getBestFigure
functions.description: Returns the best figure at the location [x,y]. It is a simple hit test. Keep in mind that only visible objects are returned.

parameters.name: y

parameters.name: blacklist
parameters.description: The figures or class which should be ignored.

parameters.name: whitelist
parameters.description: The figures or class should be considered.

functions.name: getBestLine
functions.description: Return the line which match the hands over coordinate

parameters.name: x

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: the x-coordinate for the hit test

parameters.name: lineToIgnore
parameters.description: a possible line which should be ignored for the hit test

functions.name: onDragEnter
functions.description:
Called by the framework during drag&drop operations.
Droppable can be setup with:

   $(".draw2d_droppable").draggable({
        appendTo:"#container",
        stack:"#container",
        zIndex: 27000,
        helper:"clone",
        start: function(e, ui){$(ui.helper).addClass("shadow");}
   });

Graphiti use the jQuery draggable/droppable lib. Please inspect http://jqueryui.com/demos/droppable/ for further information.

parameters.name: draggedDomNode
parameters.description: The DOM element which is currently dragging

functions.name: onDrag
functions.description:
Called if the DragDrop object is moving around.

Graphiti use the jQuery draggable/droppable lib. Please inspect http://jqueryui.com/demos/droppable/ for further information.

parameters.name: draggedDomNode
parameters.description: The dragged DOM element.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: the x coordinate of the drag

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: the y coordinate of the drag

functions.name: onDragLeave
functions.description:
Called if the DragDrop object leaving the current hover figure.

Graphiti use the jQuery draggable/droppable lib. Please inspect http://jqueryui.com/demos/droppable/ for further information.

parameters.name: draggedDomNode
parameters.description: The figure which is currently dragging

functions.name: onDrop
functions.description:
Called if the user drop the droppedDomNode onto the canvas.

Draw2D use the jQuery draggable/droppable lib. Please inspect http://jqueryui.com/demos/droppable/ for further information.

parameters.name: droppedDomNode
parameters.description: The dropped DOM element.

functions.name: fireEvent
functions.description: Execute all handlers and behaviors attached to the canvas for the given event type.

parameters.name: event
parameters.description: the event to trigger

parameters.name: args
parameters.description: optional parameters for the triggered event callback

functions.name: on
functions.description:
Attach an event handler function for one or more events to the canvas. To remove events bound with .on(), see {@link #off}.

possible events are:

  • reset
  • select

Example:

canvas.on("clear", function(emitter, event){
   alert("canvas.clear() called.");
});

canvas.on("select", function(emitter,event){
    if(event.figure!==null){
        alert("figure selected");
    }
    else{
        alert("selection cleared");
    }
});

parameters.name: event
parameters.description: One or more space-separated event types

parameters.name: callback
parameters.description: A function to execute when the event is triggered.

parameters.name: callback.emitter
parameters.description: the emitter of the event

parameters.name: callback.obj
parameters.description: optional event related data

functions.name: off
functions.description:
The .off() method removes event handlers that were attached with {@link #on}.
Calling .off() with no arguments removes all handlers attached to the canvas.

If a simple event name such as "reset" is provided, all events of that type are removed from the canvas.

parameters.name: eventOrFunction
parameters.description: the event name of the registerd function

classes.name: Connection
classes.description:
Connections figures are used to display a line between two points. The Connection interface extends {@link draw2d.shape.basic.PolyLine PolyLine}.
The source and target endpoints of a connection are each defined using a {@link draw2d.layout.anchor.ConnectionAnchor ConnectionAnchor}. These endpoints, along with any other points on the connection, are set by the connection's {@link draw2d.layout.connection.ConnectionRouter ConnectionRouter}.
Usually every connection in a drawing has the same router instance. Connections with common endpoints can share anchor instances as well.

Connection Usage

Connections are created and added just like any other figure. Unlike normal figures, you must not set the bounds of a connection. Instead, you must provide the source and target port and let the connection router calculate the connection's points. The connection then determines its own bounding box.

A connection has a simple router by default - one that can connect the source and target anchors. But additional routers are available and can be set on the connection. Some routers can handle constraints for the connection. Note that when setting a routing constraint on a connection, you must first set the router which will use that constraint.

TODO:
 A convenient way to share the router with all connections and to place connections above the drawing is to use a ConnectionLayer. The layer has a connection router property which it shares with every child that's a connection. You can update this property and easily change every connection's router at once.

Routing and Anchors

A connection always has a router and it must set at least two ports on the connection: the source and target endpoints. By default, or when set to null, the connection's routing will be performed by an internal default router. The ends are placed with the help of {@link draw2d.layout.anchor.ConnectionAnchor anchors}. An {@link draw2d.layout.anchor.ConnectionAnchor anchors} is a fixed or calculated location, usually associated with some figure. For example, the {@link draw2d.layout.anchor.ChopboxConnectionAnchor ChopboxAnchor} finds the point at which a line going to the reference point intersects a box, such as the bounds of a figure. The reference point is either the anchor at the opposite end, or a bendpoint or some other point nearest to the anchor.
{@img jsdoc_chopbox.gif ChopboxAnchor}
The router calculates the endpoints and any other points in the middle of the connection. It then sets the points on the connection by calling {@link draw2d.shape.basic.PolyLine#addPoint Polyline.addPoint}. The connection's existing point list can be reused to reduce garbage, but the points must be set on the connection anyway so that it knows about any changes made.

Adding Decorations and Children to Connections

Like most figures, Connection supports the addition of children. The children might be a label that decorate the connection. The placement of each type of decoration can vary, so a {@link draw2d.layout.locator.ConnectionLocator ConnectionLocator} is used to delegate to each child's constraint object, a Locator.

{@link draw2d.decoration.connection.Decorator Decorator} can be used to create and render a rotatable shape at the end or start of a connection like arrows or boxes. Examples are {@link draw2d.decoration.connection.ArrowDecorator ArrowDecorator}, {@link draw2d.decoration.connection.BarDecorator BarDecorator} or {@link draw2d.decoration.connection.CircleDecorator CircleDecorator}

Connection Layout

Connections extend the process of validation and layout to include routing. Since layout is the process of positioning children, routing must come first. This allows a child's locator to operate on the connection's newly-routed points.
Check out [Class System Guide](#!/guide/class_system) for additional reading.

functions.name: getAbsoluteY

functions.name: onDrag
functions.description:
Don't call them manually. This will be done by the framework.
Will be called if the object are moved via drag and drop. Sub classes can override this method to implement additional stuff. Don't forget to call the super implementation via this._super(dx, dy, dx2, dy2);

parameters.description: the x difference between the start of the drag drop operation and now

parameters.name: dy
parameters.description: the y difference between the start of the drag drop operation and now

parameters.name: dx2
parameters.description: The x diff since the last call of this dragging operation

parameters.name: dy2
parameters.description: The y diff since the last call of this dragging operation

Moves the element so it is the closest to the viewers eyes, on top of other elements. Additional the internal model changed as well.

Optional: Inserts current object in front of the given one.

functions.name: toBack

functions.name: attr
functions.description:
Read or set shape attributes.
When no value is given, reads specified attribute from the element.
When value is given, sets the attribute to that value. Multiple attributes can be set by passing an object with name-value pairs.

let figure = new draw2d.shape.basic.Rectangle(); figure.attr('x'); //=> read value figure.attr('x', 30); //=> set value

// multiple attributes: figure.attr({ x: 30, y: 40, width : 200, height: 50, cssClass: "red_border_figure" });

// it is possible to override any method of the figure as well // Instead of inheritance you can just override the callback methods // like // figure.attr({ onClick : function(){ alert("click"); } });

// or you can pass the attr values in the constructor // let clickFigure = new draw2d.shape.basic.Rectangle({ onClick : function(){ alert("click"); } });

Additional you can set the user defined values (userData) with this method using the dot-notation. User defined values are always part of the exported JSON data.

// setting multiple attributes: figure.attr({ "userData.my.property.x": 30, "userData.my.property.y": 40 });

Also set using array notation is possible for the userData:

// dot notation and array brackets: figure.attr({ "userData.my.names[0]": "John", "userData.my.names[1]": "Doe" });

The Object returned should be the equivalent structured object:

let obj = figure.getUserData();

That is, where obj is equivalent to:

let obj = { my:{ property:{ x: 30, y: 40 }, names: ["John", "Doe"] } };

returns.description: either the requested attribute if this method used as getter or this if the method uses as setter

functions.description: Return a copy of the object, filtered to only have values for the whitelisted keys.

functions.name: getHandleBBox
functions.description:
Allow dragging only when the cursor is over a specific part of the figure.
Override this method to specify the bounding box of an element or a draw2d.util.ArrayList of draw2d.geo.Rectangle of bounding boxes used to drag the figure. The returned coordinates are absolute coordinates to the canvas.

Default implementation returns null to indicate to use the complete figures as drag handle.

functions.name: onDragStart

functions.name: onDrag
functions.description:
Don't call them manually. This will be done by the framework.
Will be called if the object are moved via drag and drop. Sub classes can override this method to implement additional stuff. Don't forget to call the super implementation via this._super(dx, dy, dx2, dy2);

parameters.description: the x difference between the start of the drag drop operation and now

parameters.name: dy

parameters.name: dy2

parameters.name: ctrlKey
parameters.description: true if the ctrl key has been pressed during the event

functions.name: onPanning
functions.description:
Called by the framework if the figure returns false for the drag operation. In this case we send a "panning" event - mouseDown + mouseMove. This is very useful for UI-Widget like slider, spinner,...

// You can alternatively register an event handler with:
figure.on("panning", function(emitter, eventData){
    alert("panning of the figure called");
});

parameters.name: dx
parameters.description: the x difference between the mouse down operation and now

parameters.name: dy
parameters.description: the y difference between the mouse down operation and now

parameters.name: dx2

parameters.name: dy2
parameters.description: The y diff since the last call of this dragging operation

parameters.name: shiftKey
parameters.description: true if the shift key has been pressed during this event

parameters.name: ctrlKey
parameters.description: true if the ctrl key has been pressed during the event

functions.name: onPanningEnd
functions.description:
Called by the framework if the panning event of the figures ends. This happens after the mous up event if the panning is active.

// You can alternatively register an event handler with:
figure.on("panningEnd", function(emitter){
    alert("panning of the figure called");
});

parameters.description: optional parameters for the triggered event callback

functions.name: on
functions.description:
Attach an event handler function for one or more events to the figure. To remove events bound with .on(), see {@link #off}.

possible events are:

  • click
  • dblclick
  • move
  • resize
  • timer
  • contextmenu
  • show
  • hide
  • added
  • removed
  • change:[attr]

parameters.name: event
parameters.description: One or more space-separated event types

parameters.name: callback
parameters.description: A function to execute when the event is triggered.

parameters.name: callback.emitter
parameters.description: the emitter of the event

parameters.name: callback.obj
parameters.description: optional event related data

parameters.name: context
parameters.description: optional context of the function callback.

functions.name: off
functions.description:
The .off() method removes event handlers that were attached with {@link #on}.
Calling .off() with no arguments removes all handlers attached to the elements.

If a simple event name such as "move" is provided, all events of that type are removed from the figure.

parameters.name: eventOrFunction
parameters.description: the event name of the registerd function or the function itself

parameters.name: figureToIgnore

parameters.name: request
parameters.description: describes the Command being requested

functions.name: clone
functions.description:
Clone the figure.
You must override and implement the methods getPersistentAttributes and setPersistentAttributes for your custom figures if the have special attributes.

The clone() method performs a deep copy of the object, meaning that it copies the children, ports and decorations per default. You can control the clone procedure with the 'cloneMetaData'.

parameters.name: cloneMetaData
parameters.description: controls the clone procedure

parameters.name: cloneMetaData.excludeChildren
parameters.description: set it to true if you want exclude the children.

functions.description: Return an objects with all important attributes for XML or JSON serialization

returns.description: all attributes of the figure required for the persistency

functions.name: setPersistentAttributes
functions.description: Read all attributes from the serialized properties and transfer them into the shape.

functions.name: add
functions.description:
Add a figure at the given x/y coordinate. This method fires an event.

Example:

canvas.on("figure:add", function(emitter, event){
   alert("figure added:");
});

// or more general if you want catch all figure related events
//
canvas.on("figure", function(emitter, event){
   // use event.figure.getCanvas()===null to determine if the
   // figure part of the canvas

   alert("figure added or removed:");
});

parameters.description: The figure to add.

parameters.description: The new x coordinate of the figure or the x/y coordinate if it is an draw2d.geo.Point

functions.name: on
functions.description:
Attach an event handler function for one or more events to the canvas. To remove events bound with .on(), see {@link #off}.

possible events are:

  • reset
  • select

Example:

canvas.on("clear", function(emitter, event){
   alert("canvas.clear() called.");
});

canvas.on("select", function(emitter,event){
    if(event.figure!==null){
        alert("figure selected");
    }
    else{
        alert("selection cleared");
    }
});

parameters.description: the emitter of the event

parameters.description: optional event related data

functions.name: off
functions.description:
The .off() method removes event handlers that were attached with {@link #on}.
Calling .off() with no arguments removes all handlers attached to the canvas.

If a simple event name such as "reset" is provided, all events of that type are removed from the canvas.

parameters.name: eventOrFunction

functions.name: attr
functions.description:
Read or set shape attributes.
When no value is given, reads specified attribute from the element.
When value is given, sets the attribute to that value. Multiple attributes can be set by passing an object with name-value pairs.

let figure = new draw2d.shape.basic.Rectangle(); figure.attr('x'); //=> read value figure.attr('x', 30); //=> set value

// multiple attributes: figure.attr({ x: 30, y: 40, width : 200, height: 50, cssClass: "red_border_figure" });

// it is possible to override any method of the figure as well // Instead of inheritance you can just override the callback methods // like // figure.attr({ onClick : function(){ alert("click"); } });

// or you can pass the attr values in the constructor // let clickFigure = new draw2d.shape.basic.Rectangle({ onClick : function(){ alert("click"); } });

Additional you can set the user defined values (userData) with this method using the dot-notation. User defined values are always part of the exported JSON data.

// setting multiple attributes: figure.attr({ "userData.my.property.x": 30, "userData.my.property.y": 40 });

Also set using array notation is possible for the userData:

// dot notation and array brackets: figure.attr({ "userData.my.names[0]": "John", "userData.my.names[1]": "Doe" });

The Object returned should be the equivalent structured object:

let obj = figure.getUserData();

That is, where obj is equivalent to:

let obj = { my:{ property:{ x: 30, y: 40 }, names: ["John", "Doe"] } };

returns.description: either the requested attribute if this method used as getter or this if the method uses as setter

Install a new edit policy to the figure. Each editpolicy is able to focus on a single editing task or group of related tasks. Example for limited DragDrop behavior can be a draw2d.layout.constraint.RegionConstriantPolicy.

Calling .off() with no arguments removes all handlers attached to the elements.

functions.name: attr
functions.description:
Read or set shape attributes.
When no value is given, reads specified attribute from the element.
When value is given, sets the attribute to that value. Multiple attributes can be set by passing an object with name-value pairs.

let figure = new draw2d.shape.basic.Rectangle(); figure.attr('x'); //=> read value figure.attr('x', 30); //=> set value

// multiple attributes: figure.attr({ x: 30, y: 40, width : 200, height: 50, cssClass: "red_border_figure" });

// it is possible to override any method of the figure as well // Instead of inheritance you can just override the callback methods // like // figure.attr({ onClick : function(){ alert("click"); } });

// or you can pass the attr values in the constructor // let clickFigure = new draw2d.shape.basic.Rectangle({ onClick : function(){ alert("click"); } });

Additional you can set the user defined values (userData) with this method using the dot-notation. User defined values are always part of the exported JSON data.

// setting multiple attributes: figure.attr({ "userData.my.property.x": 30, "userData.my.property.y": 40 });

Also set using array notation is possible for the userData:

// dot notation and array brackets: figure.attr({ "userData.my.names[0]": "John", "userData.my.names[1]": "Doe" });

The Object returned should be the equivalent structured object:

let obj = figure.getUserData();

That is, where obj is equivalent to:

let obj = { my:{ property:{ x: 30, y: 40 }, names: ["John", "Doe"] } };

returns.description: either the requested attribute if this method used as getter or this if the method uses as setter

functions.name: on

Attach an event handler function for one or more events to the figure. To remove events bound with .on(), see {@link #off}.

possible events are:

  • click
  • dblclick
  • move
  • resize
  • timer
  • contextmenu
  • show
  • hide
  • added
  • removed
  • change:[attr]

parameters.name: callback
parameters.description: A function to execute when the event is triggered.

parameters.name: callback.emitter
parameters.description: the emitter of the event

parameters.name: callback.obj
parameters.description: optional event related data

parameters.name: context
parameters.description: optional context of the function callback.

functions.name: off
functions.description:
The .off() method removes event handlers that were attached with {@link #on}.
Calling .off() with no arguments removes all handlers attached to the elements.

If a simple event name such as "move" is provided, all events of that type are removed from the figure.

parameters.name: eventOrFunction
parameters.description: the event name of the registerd function or the function itself

functions.description:
set the maximal possible count of connections for this port.
This method din't delete any connection if you reduce the number and a bunch of connection are bounded already.

parameters.name: count
parameters.description: the maximal number of connection related to this port

functions.name: getMaxFanOut

functions.name: getConnectionDirection
functions.description:
Returns the direction for the connection in relation to the given port and it's parent.

Possible values:

  • draw2d.geo.Rectangle.DIRECTION_UP
  • draw2d.geo.Rectangle.DIRECTION_RIGHT
  • draw2d.geo.Rectangle.DIRECTION_DOWN
  • draw2d.geo.Rectangle.DIRECTION_LEFT

parameters.name: peerPort
parameters.description: the counterpart port

functions.name: setConnectionDirection
functions.description:
Set the direction for the connection in relation to the given port and it's parent.

Possible values:

  • up -> 0
  • right -> 1
  • down -> 2

functions.name: attr
functions.description:
Read or set shape attributes.
When no value is given, reads specified attribute from the element.
When value is given, sets the attribute to that value. Multiple attributes can be set by passing an object with name-value pairs.

let figure = new draw2d.shape.basic.Rectangle(); figure.attr('x'); //=> read value figure.attr('x', 30); //=> set value

// multiple attributes: figure.attr({ x: 30, y: 40, width : 200, height: 50, cssClass: "red_border_figure" });

// it is possible to override any method of the figure as well // Instead of inheritance you can just override the callback methods // like // figure.attr({ onClick : function(){ alert("click"); } });

// or you can pass the attr values in the constructor // let clickFigure = new draw2d.shape.basic.Rectangle({ onClick : function(){ alert("click"); } });

Additional you can set the user defined values (userData) with this method using the dot-notation. User defined values are always part of the exported JSON data.

// setting multiple attributes: figure.attr({ "userData.my.property.x": 30, "userData.my.property.y": 40 });

Also set using array notation is possible for the userData:

// dot notation and array brackets: figure.attr({ "userData.my.names[0]": "John", "userData.my.names[1]": "Doe" });

The Object returned should be the equivalent structured object:

let obj = figure.getUserData();

That is, where obj is equivalent to:

let obj = { my:{ property:{ x: 30, y: 40 }, names: ["John", "Doe"] } };

returns.description: either the requested attribute if this method used as getter or this if the method uses as setter

Install a new edit policy to the figure. Each editpolicy is able to focus on a single editing task or group of related tasks. This also allows editing behavior to be selectively reused across different figure implementations. Also, behavior can change dynamically, such as when the layouts or routing methods change.

Example for limited DragDrop behavior can be a draw2d.layout.constraint.RegionConstriantPolicy.

possible events are:

functions.name: attr
functions.description:
Read or set shape attributes.
When no value is given, reads specified attribute from the element.
When value is given, sets the attribute to that value. Multiple attributes can be set by passing an object with name-value pairs.

let figure = new draw2d.shape.basic.Rectangle(); figure.attr('x'); //=> read value figure.attr('x', 30); //=> set value

// multiple attributes: figure.attr({ x: 30, y: 40, width : 200, height: 50, cssClass: "red_border_figure" });

// it is possible to override any method of the figure as well // Instead of inheritance you can just override the callback methods // like // figure.attr({ onClick : function(){ alert("click"); } });

// or you can pass the attr values in the constructor // let clickFigure = new draw2d.shape.basic.Rectangle({ onClick : function(){ alert("click"); } });

Additional you can set the user defined values (userData) with this method using the dot-notation. User defined values are always part of the exported JSON data.

// setting multiple attributes: figure.attr({ "userData.my.property.x": 30, "userData.my.property.y": 40 });

Also set using array notation is possible for the userData:

// dot notation and array brackets: figure.attr({ "userData.my.names[0]": "John", "userData.my.names[1]": "Doe" });

The Object returned should be the equivalent structured object:

let obj = figure.getUserData();

That is, where obj is equivalent to:

let obj = { my:{ property:{ x: 30, y: 40 }, names: ["John", "Doe"] } };

returns.description: either the requested attribute if this method used as getter or this if the method uses as setter

functions.name: on
functions.description:
Attach an event handler function for one or more events to the figure. To remove events bound with .on(), see {@link #off}.

possible events are:

  • click
  • dblclick
  • move
  • resize
  • timer
  • contextmenu
  • show
  • hide
  • added
  • removed
  • change:[attr]

functions.name: off
functions.description:
The .off() method removes event handlers that were attached with {@link #on}.
Calling .off() with no arguments removes all handlers attached to the elements.

If a simple event name such as "move" is provided, all events of that type are removed from the figure.

functions.name: attr
functions.description:
Read or set shape attributes.
When no value is given, reads specified attribute from the element.
When value is given, sets the attribute to that value. Multiple attributes can be set by passing an object with name-value pairs.

let figure = new draw2d.shape.basic.Rectangle(); figure.attr('x'); //=> read value figure.attr('x', 30); //=> set value

// multiple attributes: figure.attr({ x: 30, y: 40, width : 200, height: 50, cssClass: "red_border_figure" });

// it is possible to override any method of the figure as well // Instead of inheritance you can just override the callback methods // like // figure.attr({ onClick : function(){ alert("click"); } });

// or you can pass the attr values in the constructor // let clickFigure = new draw2d.shape.basic.Rectangle({ onClick : function(){ alert("click"); } });

Additional you can set the user defined values (userData) with this method using the dot-notation. User defined values are always part of the exported JSON data.

// setting multiple attributes: figure.attr({ "userData.my.property.x": 30, "userData.my.property.y": 40 });

Also set using array notation is possible for the userData:

// dot notation and array brackets: figure.attr({ "userData.my.names[0]": "John", "userData.my.names[1]": "Doe" });

The Object returned should be the equivalent structured object:

let obj = figure.getUserData();

That is, where obj is equivalent to:

let obj = { my:{ property:{ x: 30, y: 40 }, names: ["John", "Doe"] } };

returns.description: either the requested attribute if this method used as getter or this if the method uses as setter

Install a new edit policy to the figure. Each editpolicy is able to focus on a single editing task or group of related tasks. This also allows editing behavior to be selectively reused across different figure implementations. Also, behavior can change dynamically, such as when the layouts or routing methods change.

Example for limited DragDrop behavior can be a draw2d.layout.constraint.RegionConstriantPolicy.

Add a child figure to the figure. The hands over figure doesn't support drag&drop operations. It's only a decorator for the connection.

canvas.add( start);

functions.name: on
functions.description:
Attach an event handler function for one or more events to the figure. To remove events bound with .on(), see {@link #off}.

possible events are:

  • click
  • dblclick
  • move
  • resize
  • timer
  • contextmenu
  • show
  • hide
  • added
  • removed
  • change:[attr]

functions.name: off
functions.description:
The .off() method removes event handlers that were attached with {@link #on}.
Calling .off() with no arguments removes all handlers attached to the elements.

If a simple event name such as "move" is provided, all events of that type are removed from the figure.

functions.name: attr
functions.description:
Read or set shape attributes.
When no value is given, reads specified attribute from the element.
When value is given, sets the attribute to that value. Multiple attributes can be set by passing an object with name-value pairs.

let figure = new draw2d.shape.basic.Rectangle(); figure.attr('x'); //=> read value figure.attr('x', 30); //=> set value

// multiple attributes: figure.attr({ x: 30, y: 40, width : 200, height: 50, cssClass: "red_border_figure" });

// it is possible to override any method of the figure as well // Instead of inheritance you can just override the callback methods // like // figure.attr({ onClick : function(){ alert("click"); } });

// or you can pass the attr values in the constructor // let clickFigure = new draw2d.shape.basic.Rectangle({ onClick : function(){ alert("click"); } });

Additional you can set the user defined values (userData) with this method using the dot-notation. User defined values are always part of the exported JSON data.

// setting multiple attributes: figure.attr({ "userData.my.property.x": 30, "userData.my.property.y": 40 });

Also set using array notation is possible for the userData:

// dot notation and array brackets: figure.attr({ "userData.my.names[0]": "John", "userData.my.names[1]": "Doe" });

The Object returned should be the equivalent structured object:

let obj = figure.getUserData();

That is, where obj is equivalent to:

let obj = { my:{ property:{ x: 30, y: 40 }, names: ["John", "Doe"] } };

returns.description: either the requested attribute if this method used as getter or this if the method uses as setter

functions.description:
Install a new edit policy to the figure. Each editpolicy is able to focus on a single editing task or group of related tasks. This also allows editing behavior to be selectively reused across different figure implementations. Also, behavior can change dynamically, such as when the layouts or routing methods change.

Example for limited DragDrop behavior can be a draw2d.layout.constraint.RegionConstriantPolicy.

Add a child figure to the figure. The hands over figure doesn't support drag&drop operations. It's only a decorator for the connection.
Mainly for labels or other decorations

canvas.add( start);

Default implementation returns null to indicate to use the complete figures as drag handle.

functions.name: on
functions.description:
Attach an event handler function for one or more events to the figure. To remove events bound with .on(), see {@link #off}.

possible events are:

  • click
  • dblclick
  • move
  • resize
  • timer
  • contextmenu
  • show
  • hide
  • added
  • removed
  • change:[attr]

parameters.name: event
parameters.description: One or more space-separated event types

parameters.name: callback
parameters.description: A function to execute when the event is triggered.

parameters.name: callback.emitter
parameters.description: the emitter of the event

parameters.name: callback.obj
parameters.description: optional event related data

parameters.name: context
parameters.description: optional context of the function callback.

functions.name: off
functions.description:
The .off() method removes event handlers that were attached with {@link #on}.
Calling .off() with no arguments removes all handlers attached to the elements.

If a simple event name such as "move" is provided, all events of that type are removed from the figure.

parameters.name: eventOrFunction
parameters.description: the event name of the registerd function or the function itself

functions.name: attr
functions.description:
Read or set shape attributes.
When no value is given, reads specified attribute from the element.
When value is given, sets the attribute to that value. Multiple attributes can be set by passing an object with name-value pairs.

let figure = new draw2d.shape.basic.Rectangle(); figure.attr('x'); //=> read value figure.attr('x', 30); //=> set value

// multiple attributes: figure.attr({ x: 30, y: 40, width : 200, height: 50, cssClass: "red_border_figure" });

// it is possible to override any method of the figure as well // Instead of inheritance you can just override the callback methods // like // figure.attr({ onClick : function(){ alert("click"); } });

// or you can pass the attr values in the constructor // let clickFigure = new draw2d.shape.basic.Rectangle({ onClick : function(){ alert("click"); } });

Additional you can set the user defined values (userData) with this method using the dot-notation. User defined values are always part of the exported JSON data.

// setting multiple attributes: figure.attr({ "userData.my.property.x": 30, "userData.my.property.y": 40 });

Also set using array notation is possible for the userData:

// dot notation and array brackets: figure.attr({ "userData.my.names[0]": "John", "userData.my.names[1]": "Doe" });

The Object returned should be the equivalent structured object:

let obj = figure.getUserData();

That is, where obj is equivalent to:

let obj = { my:{ property:{ x: 30, y: 40 }, names: ["John", "Doe"] } };

returns.description: either the requested attribute if this method used as getter or this if the method uses as setter

functions.name: pick

functions.name: installEditPolicy
functions.description:
Install a new edit policy to the figure. Each editpolicy is able to focus on a single editing task or group of related tasks. This also allows editing behavior to be selectively reused across different figure implementations. Also, behavior can change dynamically, such as when the layouts or routing methods change.

Example for limited DragDrop behavior can be a draw2d.layout.constraint.RegionConstriantPolicy.

functions.name: add
functions.description:
Add a child figure to the figure. The hands over figure doesn't support drag&drop operations. It's only a decorator for the connection.
Mainly for labels or other decorations

let start = new draw2d.shape.node.Start({x:80, y:150}); start.add(new draw2d.shape.basic.Label({text:"Test Label"}), new draw2d.layout.locator.TopLocator());

canvas.add( start);

functions.name: getAbsolutePosition
functions.description: Returns the absolute y-position of the port.

functions.name: getAbsoluteBounds
functions.description: Returns the absolute y-position of the port.

functions.name: setPosition
functions.description:
Set the position of the object.

// Alternatively you can use the attr method:
figure.attr({
  x: x,
  y: y
});

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The new x coordinate of the figure or the x/y coordinate if it is an draw2d.geo.Point

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The new y coordinate of the figure

functions.name: getPosition
functions.description: Get the current position of the figure

functions.name: translate
functions.description: Translate the figure with the given x/y offset.

parameters.name: dx
parameters.description: The x offset to translate

parameters.name: dy
parameters.description: The y offset to translate

functions.name: setBoundingBox
functions.description:
Set the bounding box of the figure

// Alternatively you can use the attr method:
figure.attr({
  width: w,
  height: h,
  x: x,
  y: y
});

// or
figure.attr({
  boundingBox: {x:1, y:100, width:30, height:30}
});

functions.name: getBoundingBox
functions.description: Returns the bounding box of the figure in absolute position to the canvas.

functions.name: hitTest
functions.description: Detect whenever the hands over coordinate is inside the figure. The default implementation is a simple bounding box test.

functions.name: setDraggable
functions.description: Switch on/off the drag drop behaviour of this object

parameters.name: flag
parameters.description: The new drag drop indicator

functions.name: isDraggable
functions.description: Get the Drag drop enable flag

functions.name: isResizeable
functions.description: Returns the true if the figure can be resized.

functions.name: setResizeable
functions.description:
You can change the resizeable behaviour of this object. Hands over [false] and the figure has no resizehandles if you select them with the mouse.

// Alternatively you can use the attr method:
figure.attr({
  resizeable: flag
});

parameters.name: flag
parameters.description: The resizeable flag.

functions.name: isSelectable
functions.description: Indicates whenever the element is selectable by user interaction or API.

functions.name: setSelectable
functions.description: You can change the selectable behavior of this object. Hands over [false] and the figure has no selection handles if you try to select them with the mouse.

parameters.name: flag
parameters.description: The selectable flag.

functions.name: isStrechable
functions.description:
Return true if the object doesn't care about the aspect ratio. You can change the height and width independent.

Replaced with "getKeepAspectRatio"

functions.name: isDeleteable
functions.description: Return false if you avoid that the user can delete your figure. Sub class can override this method.

functions.name: setDeleteable
functions.description: Set the flag if the shape is deleteable.

parameters.name: flag
parameters.description: enable or disable flag for the delete operation

functions.name: setParent
functions.description: Set the parent of this figure. Don't call them manually.

parameters.name: parent
parameters.description: The new parent of this figure

functions.name: getParent
functions.description: Get the parent of this figure.

functions.name: contains
functions.description:
Check to see if a figure is a descendant of another figure.
The contains() method returns true if the figure provided by the argument is a descendant of this figure, whether it is a direct child or nested more deeply. Otherwise, it returns false.

parameters.name: containedFigure
parameters.description: The figure that may be contained by (a descendant of) this figure.

functions.name: getRoot
functions.description: Get the top most parent of this figure. This can be an layout figure or parent container

functions.name: setComposite
functions.description: Set the assigned composite of this figure.

parameters.name: composite
parameters.description: The assigned composite of this figure

functions.name: getComposite
functions.description: Get the assigned composite of this figure.

functions.name: fireEvent
functions.description: Execute all handlers and behaviors attached to the figure for the given event type.

parameters.name: event
parameters.description: the event to trigger

parameters.name: args
parameters.description: optional parameters for the triggered event callback

functions.name: on
functions.description:
Attach an event handler function for one or more events to the figure. To remove events bound with .on(), see {@link #off}.

possible events are:

  • click
  • dblclick
  • move
  • resize
  • timer
  • contextmenu
  • show
  • hide
  • added
  • removed
  • change:[attr]

parameters.name: event
parameters.description: One or more space-separated event types

parameters.name: callback
parameters.description: A function to execute when the event is triggered.

parameters.name: callback.emitter
parameters.description: the emitter of the event

parameters.name: callback.obj
parameters.description: optional event related data

parameters.name: context
parameters.description: optional context of the function callback.

functions.name: off
functions.description:
The .off() method removes event handlers that were attached with {@link #on}.
Calling .off() with no arguments removes all handlers attached to the elements.

If a simple event name such as "move" is provided, all events of that type are removed from the figure.

parameters.name: eventOrFunction
parameters.description: the event name of the registerd function or the function itself

functions.name: getBestChild
functions.description: Returns the best figure at the location [x,y]. It is a simple hit test. Keep in mind that only visible objects are returned.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x position.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y position.

parameters.name: figureToIgnore
parameters.description: The figures which should be ignored.
